Currently, objects will directly instantiate the EnumField
class, passing in the list of valid enum values. This is

commit_message:
Add migration_type and hidden to Migration database model

This adds an enumeration for migration_type to the schema. It does not
do any data translation in the schema migration, and allows the column
to be nullable so that we don't have to act on existing migrations.
This means that any outstanding migrations in the database will need to
be handled lazily by the upper layers.

This also adds a flag called hidden, defaulting to False. Since we are
using this new type field to record potentially admin-initiated actions,
it is desirable to allow them to be hidden from regular users at times.
This adds that field to the database so that we can support that in the
migration APIs.

    cfg.BoolOpt('myflag',

subject: Set IPset hash type to 'net' instead of 'ip'
commit_message:
Set IPset hash type to 'net' instead of 'ip'

The previous hash type was 'ip' and this caused a major
issue with the allowed address pairs extension since it
results in CIDRs being passed to ipset. When the hash type
is 'ip', a CIDR is completely enumerated into all of its
addresses so 10.100.0.0/16 results in ~65k entries. This
meant a single allowed_address_pairs entry could easily
exhaust an entire set.

This patch changes the hash type to 'net', which is designed
to handle a CIDRs as a single entry.

This patch also changes the names of the ipsets because
creating an ipset with different parameters will cause an
error and our ipset manager code isn't robust enough to handle
that at this time.

subject: Make `tgtd' to open backing device with O_DIRECT
commit_message:
Make `tgtd' to open backing device with O_DIRECT

The `tgtd' iSCSI target daemon opens a backing device using page cache
or cache write-through. Both of these degrade performance while first
causes `qemu' to hang-up during the fsync (2) call on the iSCSI device.

subject: Common list method for proxies
commit_message:
Common list method for proxies

This change introduces a common list method for proxies, enabling the
use of query parameters to be used in limiting the data returned by a
request. In accepting query parameters, it also handles accepting
parameters that are resources by converting the resource into the
appropriate ID, so you can, e.g., get all servers that are running with
a particular image via that image's resource instance.

The Proxy._list method accept query parameters as keyword arguments that
are passed on to Resource.list, which are then passed on to
Resource.page, which are then passed on to session.get via the params=
parameters, which then causes the requests library to append those
key/value pairs onto the request URL as query parameters. From each
proxy's use of this common class, the approach was taken to accept the
query parameters in, e.g., compute.servers, as keyword arguments rather
than explicit parameters. This was done as there are a large amount of
parameters accepted by not just the /servers resource, but by many
others around other services.

As with other common methods for proxies, this change applies the base
method to the servers method (formerly known as list_servers).
Additionally, this method accepting query parameters to limit responses
will work in conjunction with the `get` methods with the aim of
converging the get/list/find set of methods to just get/list.

As with other changes like this, it introduces a second test
verification method that duplicates an existing one since we'll have two
APIs temporarily, but that will be removed once we've converged on this
API for listing.

Change-Id: I5e6d62a649a9f492433ea76d6eeaa754884e40ec

leads to a race condition. The VLAN is started before the bond, so
when os-net-config tries to bring up the VLAN it will fail. This

then interfaces, and finally VLANs. This change also adds the OVS_BRIDGE=
value to the ifcfg file for the bond, which helps to ensure the bond will
activate when ifup is run.

the DEFROUTE=no in ifcfg files. I also noticed that in 4 places in

subject: Erase non-root disks first
commit_message:
Erase non-root disks first

This change adjusts the order that the system block devices (disks)
are erased as part erase_node MCollective action.  This change queries
the block devices for the system and uses lsblk to determine if the
device has a partition that is currently being used for mounting /.

the root disks.  This done to ensure that data disks are properly
cleaned up and are not accidentally left intact on the chance that
purging the root disk causes the erase script to fail.

commit_message:
Send node_deletion task within other subtasks

We have to execute node deletion task only when provision, deployment
and other tasks are in the database. Otherwise, it may be executed
too quickly (e.g. our tests) and this will affect parent task calculation:
it will be marked as 'ready' because by that time it have only two
subtasks - network_check and node_deletion - and they're ready.

As a fix, we could send task to execution when all others tasks are
in the database.

From rsync's man page:
-z, --compress
With this option, rsync compresses the file data as it is sent to the

something that is useful over a slow connection.

A configurable option has been added to allow rsync to compress, but only

might slow down the syncing process.

change if required. In case of ssync, we could explore faster
